channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-14473] Compute region locality in parallel
item.description:
Right now on large clusters it's necessary to turn off the locality balance cost as it takes too long to compute the region locality. This is because it's computed when need in serial.

We should compute this in parallel before it's needed.

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: So hbase.master.balancer.regionLocationCacheTime changed meaning from mins to millisecs? And the default you use got 8 time bigger?

Yeah, changed from mins to millis so that it fits with other configs ( basically everything in HBase is millis ). I don't think that anyone has actually changed this config ever ( we might want to just remove it completely).
Make it 8 times longer because it's physically impossible for locality to change that much in 30 mins on a cluster of any real size and anything that's so small that you can transfer it in < 30 mins will fit in cache anyway so locality isn't too big an issue.

Thanks for explanation, looks good to me, +1.

This

@return true if region locations got refreshed.

is inconsistent w/ what it actually returns, right? Should be "if locations for some user tables got refreshed"?

I suppose 5 hardcoded thread in threadpool are just fine. Also seems this class missing audience annotation, do you want to add Private one?

against master branch at commit 5e26ae043dde217aeda29d9b67e290728adade89.

Please justify why no new tests are needed for this patch.
Also please list what manual steps were performed to verify this patch.

Elliott Clark What do you think about that make region location cache time configurable again? Large cluster may need increase cache time to reduce the region locality computation. Small cluster may need config the cache time same with balancer period to response the locality change.
